title: Caryopteris
text:
Caryopteris (bluebeard; ) is a genus of <a href="flowering%20plant">flowering plant</a>s in the family <a href="Lamiaceae">Lamiaceae</a> (formerly often placed in the family <a href="Verbenaceae">Verbenaceae</a>). They are native to east <a href="Asia">Asia</a> (<a href="China">China</a>, <a href="Korea">Korea</a>, <a href="Japan">Japan</a>, <a href="Mongolia">Mongolia</a>).
They are <a href="herbaceous%20plant">herbaceous plant</a>s or small <a href="shrub">shrub</a>s growing to 1–4 m tall. The <a href="leaf">leaves</a> are opposite, simple ovate to lanceolate, with an entire or crenate margin; they are often aromatic. The blue or white <a href="flower">flower</a>s are pollinated by butterflies and bumblebees. The <a href="fruit">fruit</a> is a four-valved <a href="capsule%20%28fruit%29">capsule</a> containing four seeds.
Cultivation and uses.
Though several "Caryopteris" species are grown in <a href="botanical%20garden">botanical garden</a>s, as <a href="ornamental%20plant">ornamental plant</a>s the species have largely been superseded in gardens by the <a href="Hybrid%20%28biology%29%23Hybrid%20plants">hybrid</a> "Caryopteris" × "clandonensis" ("C. incana" × "C. mongholica"). The accidental cross that produced it occurred in the garden of Arthur Simmonds at Clandon, near Guildford, Surrey. In 1930, wishing to propagate "C. mongholica", he gathered seeds from a plant that was growing near "C. mastacanthus". When the seedlings eventually flowered in their second year, hybrids appeared. The final selection, however, was made of a self-sown volunteer that appeared under "C. mastacanthus", and eventually smothered it. It began winning <a href="Royal%20Horticultural%20Society">Royal Horticultural Society</a> medals in 1933. This small, <a href="deciduous">deciduous</a>, aromatic shrub has grey-green leaves and produces masses of blue flowers in late summer.
"Caryopteris" × "clandonensis", an unusual plant in American gardens in the 1960s, has become more familiar there, especially in <a href="xeriscaping">xeriscaping</a>.
Like "<a href="Buddleja">Buddleja</a>", the woody stems can die back in the winter, particularly in colder climates and on heavy soils. They prefer well-drained, sandy soil in full sun, but does not need especially rich soil or constant moisture.
Leaves and herbaceous stems have a <a href="terpene">terpene</a> aroma like <a href="eucalyptus">eucalyptus</a>, especially when lightly bruised.
Cultivars.
There are several <a href="cultivars">cultivars</a> with flowers in shades of blue or white, including 'Blue Mist', 'Heavenly Blue', 'Longwood Blue', 'Dark Knight', 'Summer Sorbet' and 'Pershore'.
